Sorry for this double-post, but if you don't allow direct input-
>output co=
nnections and probably recurrent connections (such that go 
from one hidden=
 node to another one in the same layer), then you have 
made assumptions fo=
r a layered network topology. I guess that such a 
topology (space) is enou=
gh to solve the problem, but it restricts the 
real power of the CPPN, to d=
escribe any possible topology. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jason=
 Gauci" <jgmath2000@...> wrote:
>
> Regarding the number of connections, th=
ere are two things to note:
> 
> First, HyperNEAT uses all 64 input nodes, =
even the ones which cannot
> legally contain a piece.  The reason why is be=
cause we wanted to
> compare HyperNEAT's approach to discovering geometric =
regularities
> with NEAT-EI's approach of using a priori engineered regular=
ities.  
If
> we disabled the connections that would never be activated, we=
 would 
be
> cheating, in a sense, by providing a priori domain-specific 
k=
nowledge
> to the algorithm.  The only a priori knowledge needed involves t=
he
> size of the layers in the substrate and the hidden layer
> configurati=
on.  In this case, the extra connections have no impact 
on
> the network, =
but I left them in ti keep with the spirit of the 
experiment.
> 
> Second,=
 all 64*64 + 64*1 (4160) connections in the substrate are not
> always expr=
essed.  If the CPPN outputs a value with a magnitude less
> than 0.2, the c=
onnection weight is forced to absolute 0, disabling 
the
> connection.  Con=
nections which are disabled are considered to not
> exist, so the 3979 numb=
er implies that some of the connections were
> not expressed in that substr=
ate.
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@> wrote:
> >
> =
> 
> > On Apr 11, 2008, at 9:38 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> > > Jason Gauc=
i and I are pleased to share with you new results with
> > > HyperNEAT  in =
our new paper to appear in the Twenty-Third AAAI
> > > Conference on Artifi=
cial Intelligence (2008), "A Case Study on 
the
> > > Critical Role of Geom=
etric Regularity in Machine Learning."
> > 
> > 
> > Cool, I enjoyed the pa=
per, thanks Jason and Ken.
> > 
> > I have a few questions:
> > 
> > * Was =
the 4in/2out CPPN arbitrarily chosen?
> > * Why not a 6in/1out (xyz, xyz, o=
ut) - which seems more natural 
to me?
> > * Was more than one CPPN configu=
ration tried?  What was the 
process?
> > * Was more than one substrate con=
figuration tried?  ...
> > * What was the full connection pattern through t=
he substrate?  
You  
> > mention the 129 nodes (which makes sense), but wh=
at are the 3979  
> > connections?
> > * Did you try against any opponents =
other than Xcheckers?
> > * Have you experimented with coevolution?
> > 
> =
> Thanks again for the great work.
> > --
> > Stephen Waits
> > steve@
> > =
http://swaits.com/
> >
